title: Missing Protection Mechanism in Mail Servers allows malicious user to use staff.ratelimited.me email could lead to identity theft.

profile.name: RATELIMITED
profile.about: RATELIMITED is an opensource, no-bullshit file hosting service

vulnerability_information:
Hello ratelimited,

I'm not really sure how your mail servers being configured but i guess there is a mis-configuration or missing protection mechanism that fails to verify if the email that is going to be sent are only made by authorized ratelimited staff only. From this point of view a malicious user could sent an email to a victim by using valid and email owned by staffs of ratelimited and to be specific one of them are `gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me` and i can surely tell it is based on #369581 wherein a team member acknowledge the hacker that is will be given a reward for efforts.

### So what now ?
If a malicious user could use `gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me` to send emails through the abuse of misconfigured mail server with missing protection, they can spread fake message from this point and make the reputation of ratelimited staffs and management bad from others point of view.

### POC 
I've attack my own email and tries to exploit the issue.
Here my gmail account has been received email from `gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me` says that i've received reward from ratelimited. If a normal user would received this email, they will not hesitate to claim the reward thinking that came from and request being done and sent by legitimate staff from ratelimited but it is actually not.
{F412930} 

### How could we verify this ?
Here is the steps to reproduce the issue:
- I use 3rd party email faker `emkei.cz` to use spoof email of `gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me`.
- Just compose a normal email and not forget to put email of the victim.
- Send the email.

### Still, who cares or implement mail protections from their servers ?
Hackerone itself is already done this way back years ago. They configured their mail server so whenever a malicious user could use @hackerone.com and tries to send mail using it from distributing messages. Hackerone mail server will prevent this before sending it to desired victim. And so facebook does, In case you want to verify this. Try the steps to reproduce above against the said website and you see the attack will never succeed on `*@hackerone.com` nor `*.facebook.com`.

> Don't get me wrong but this attack only made possible by opening ratelimited itself a window for exploitation.

Regards,
Mart Gil

## Impact

Could distribute fake email content/files using `gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me` or any email used by ratelimited. As a result, ratelimited will have a bad reputation and this can also be use by any counterpart company of ratelimited.
vulnerability_information_html:
Hello ratelimited,

I'm not really sure how your mail servers being configured but i guess there is a mis-configuration or missing protection mechanism that fails to verify if the email that is going to be sent are only made by authorized ratelimited staff only. From this point of view a malicious user could sent an email to a victim by using valid and email owned by staffs of ratelimited and to be specific one of them are gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me and i can surely tell it is based on #369581 wherein a team member acknowledge the hacker that is will be given a reward for efforts.

So what now ?

If a malicious user could use gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me to send emails through the abuse of misconfigured mail server with missing protection, they can spread fake message from this point and make the reputation of ratelimited staffs and management bad from others point of view.

POC

I've attack my own email and tries to exploit the issue.
Here my gmail account has been received email from gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me says that i've received reward from ratelimited. If a normal user would received this email, they will not hesitate to claim the reward thinking that came from and request being done and sent by legitimate staff from ratelimited but it is actually not.
{F412930}

How could we verify this ?

Here is the steps to reproduce the issue:

  • I use 3rd party email faker emkei.cz to use spoof email of gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me.
  • Just compose a normal email and not forget to put email of the victim.
  • Send the email.

Still, who cares or implement mail protections from their servers ?

Hackerone itself is already done this way back years ago. They configured their mail server so whenever a malicious user could use @hackerone.com and tries to send mail using it from distributing messages. Hackerone mail server will prevent this before sending it to desired victim. And so facebook does, In case you want to verify this. Try the steps to reproduce above against the said website and you see the attack will never succeed on *@hackerone.com nor *.facebook.com.

Don't get me wrong but this attack only made possible by opening ratelimited itself a window for exploitation.

Regards,
Mart Gil

Impact

Could distribute fake email content/files using gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me or any email used by ratelimited. As a result, ratelimited will have a bad reputation and this can also be use by any counterpart company of ratelimited.

activities.message:
You might consider checking these following reports for more information :
- https://hackerone.com/reports/182467
- https://hackerone.com/reports/575

This issue was i guess a worth for fixing or just make the impact goes to minimal. If this issue might not be part as your concern. I will love to learn and know the reason why in exchange only for knowledge.

Kind Regards,
Mart Gil

additional_data.old_title: Missing Protection Mechanism in Mail Servers allows malicious user to use staff.ratelimited.com email could lead to identity theft.
additional_data.new_title: Missing Protection Mechanism in Mail Servers allows malicious user to use staff.ratelimited.me email could lead to identity theft.

activities.message:
Hey there Mart,

Thank you for reporting this to us. The internal Jira reference for this issue is H1-5.

This is a configuration mishap on my part, as I did not include the DKIM & SPF records for `staff.ratelimited.me`. I will be fixing this issue as soon as possible.

Regards,
George
activities.markdown_message:

Regards,

activities.message:
Hello @gtsatsis,
I was just woke up this morning and quickly check this issue haha, and it seems it doesn't fixed yet. As i confirm the misconfiguration was already been there as i can still sent email using `gtsatsis@staff.ratelimited.me` as one of the `@staff.ratelimited.me`.

{F413143}
My apology for slight mistake of mine in title of this report, And Thank you for bringing your attention to this.

Again if there is anything else i could help, Please do let me know.

Good Day,
Mart Gil

Hey there Mart,

Would you happen to know how to fix this? I've added both SPF & DKIM, but I cannot do any server-side configuration, as our e-mail is powered by Yandex.

Regards,
George

activities.message: Hi @gtsatsis i use this website https://toolbox.googleapps.com/apps/messageheader/ to analyze the header from message and it does detect the domain from which the email came from in this case `emkei.cz`.
activities.markdown_message: Hi @gtsatsis i use this website https://toolbox.googleapps.com/apps/messageheader/ to analyze the header from message and it does detect the domain from which the email came from in this case emkei.cz.

activities.message:
Sorry for my very limited actions for help you out from these issue but i am really trying my best :) and this is just a little bit difficult situation due to black-box testing. 

##### Please try the following as much as possible
Recognize email spoofing
- Check return path
- Check originating IP

To prevent email spoofing
- Setup SPF Record - for setting up SPF records please do follow https://yandex.com/support/domain/set-mail/spf.html instruction.
- Setup DKIM/DMARK -  for setting up DKIM signature please do follow https://yandex.com/support/domain/set-mail/dkim.html instruction.

and if possible please do let me know that are those steps or action that is being try already. But again for just server-side mitigation only try to follow my suggestion above on how to recognize email spoofing.

Kind Regards,
Mart Gil
activities.markdown_message:
Sorry for my very limited actions for help you out from these issue but i am really trying my best :) and this is just a little bit difficult situation due to black-box testing.

Please try the following as much as possible

Recognize email spoofing

  • Check return path
  • Check originating IP

To prevent email spoofing

  • Setup SPF Record - for setting up SPF records please do follow https://yandex.com/support/domain/set-mail/spf.html instruction.
  • Setup DKIM/DMARK - for setting up DKIM signature please do follow https://yandex.com/support/domain/set-mail/dkim.html instruction.

and if possible please do let me know that are those steps or action that is being try already. But again for just server-side mitigation only try to follow my suggestion above on how to recognize email spoofing.

Kind Regards,
Mart Gil

activities.message:
**Please do visit this also as this might be the fix for this issue as my final resort and i'm confident it is:**
*This include specified configuration for `@gmail.com` accounts*
https://support.google.com/a/answer/33786

And another one from yandex https://yandex.com/support/connect/dns/spf.html
**They also take note for 72 hours to take effect of the configuration**, and so im not in a hurry so in fact i will keep an eye on this and check it by 2 days or so if needed to verify the fix.

I'm very happy working with you guys not only for helping out people from fixing issue against their site but also i'm learning new things and gain new experience.

Cheers,
Mart Gil

Hello @gtsatsis it looks like this issue has been fixed :D I can confirm the fix by sending another spoofed email using @staff.ratelimited.me and this time it has been thrown to spam section of gmail.

Spoofed email in spam section.

{F414823}

activities.message:
Hey there @sxw,

Normally, I'd close this as resolved already, as you've verified, but it seems that it hasn't worked on my end(?)..

https://once-i-was-11-years-old-my.daddy-told.me/go-get-yourself-a-wife-or-youll-be-lonely/cdejf6bfvz.png

I came up with a seemingly real e-mail, and Google passed it through without an issue.

I have set up mail.staff.ratelimited.me to CNAME to domain.mail.yandex.net, DKIM under the mail selector of the staff subdomain, and SPF for staff.ratelimited.me.

I am currently unaware of any other solutions I could take.

activities.message: I've been using emkei.cz to test, and in all cases, my emails that looked legit passed through GMail's spam filters, I've got no idea anymore
activities.markdown_message: I've been using emkei.cz to test, and in all cases, my emails that looked legit passed through GMail's spam filters, I've got no idea anymore

activities.message:
I guess that should be the only way to mitigation in that issue instead. Google just separted spoof emails in `spam` from legitimate emails in `inbox` then they are only including warnings from the reciever about potential harm  againsts to it. In fact in #575 they took the same issue and this is only the fixed by just moving spoof email to `spam`.

I hope this helps,
Mart Gil

activities.markdown_message: Well, I guess we've done literally everything in our power. Resolved, although, will look into it more.

activities.message:
Hey @sxw,

I wish I could give you even more reputation right now.

I have found the issue to be that I had forgotten to include `-all` at the end of the SPF record. Now a full FAIL happens upon SPF checks, and it will be directly put into spam!

Regards,
George
activities.markdown_message:
Hey @sxw,

I wish I could give you even more reputation right now.

I have found the issue to be that I had forgotten to include -all at the end of the SPF record. Now a full FAIL happens upon SPF checks, and it will be directly put into spam!

Regards,
George

activities.message:

Regards,
Mart Gil
